meaning: The word 'been' is the past participle of the verb 'be'. It is used to indicate a state of being or existence in the past, often in perfect tenses to show that an action has been completed at some point before now.
etymology: The word 'been' originates from Old English 'bēon', which is a variant of 'beon' meaning 'to be'. It has evolved through Middle English, retaining its core function as a verb.
sentences: I have been to Paris twice.
It has been a long day.
She had been waiting for hours before the show started.
short_stories: Once upon a time, there was a traveler who had been to every corner of the world. His stories of the places he had been inspired many to explore beyond their horizons.
In a small village, there was an old tree that had been standing for centuries. It had been a silent witness to the changing seasons and the lives of the villagers.
poetry:
I have been one acquainted with the night.
I have walked out in rain—and back in rain.
I have outwalked the furthest city light.
- Robert Frost, 'Acquainted with the Night'

Where I have been
And where I am going to
Are questions that linger
In the twilight of my thoughts.
- Anonymous
